The proof of the four colour theorem was: The proof of the four colour theorem was famously tricky, and comes from graph theory, where mathematicians investigate an equivalent problem of colouring vertices of a network so that no edge has endpoints the same colour. The original four-colour proof was attempted by Alfred Kempe in 1879, but unfortunately Percy John Heawood found an error 11 years later. However his work was not useless, as Percy was able to prove the five-colour theorem (that one can colour a map with no two adjacent regions the sample colour using at most 5 colours) based on Kempe's work. The four colour theorem was finally proved in 1976 by Kenneth Appel, Wolfgang Haken, and John Koch using a computer to check it. This was the first major theorem to be proved using a computer. They checked around 1500 configurations using about 1200 hours of computer time. Some people were sceptical about a proof using a computer but independent verification soon convinced everyone that the four colour theorem had finally been proved.
